video.title: WebAssembly and the Death of JavaScript
video.description:
For more than 20 years JavaScript has been the only 'native' language of the web. That's all changed with the release of WebAssembly. This talk will look at what WebAssembly is, why it matters and crucially what it means for JavaScript and the future of web development. JavaScript brought interactivity to the web more than 20 years ago, and despite numerous challengers, it is still the only language supported by browser. However, as those 20 years have passed we've moved from adding a little interactivity to largely static sites, to creating complex JavaScript-heavy single page applications. Throughout this journey, the way we use JavaScript itself has also changed. Gone are the days of writing simple code snippets that are run directly in the browser. Nowadays we transpile, minify, tree-shake and more, treating the JavaScript virtual machine as a compilation target.

The problem is, JavaScript isn't a very good compilation target, because it simply wasn't designed to be one.

Born out of asm.js, a somewhat crazy concept dreamt up by Mozilla, WebAssembly was designed from the ground-up as an efficient compilation target for the web. It promises smaller payloads, rapid parsing and validation and consistent performance ... and it's ready to use, right now!

This talk will look at what's wrong with the way we are using JavaScript today and why we need WebAssembly. It will delve into the internals, giving a quick tour of the WebAssembly instruction set, memory and security model, before moving on to the more practical aspects of using it with Rust, C++ and JavaScript. Finally we'll do some crystal-ball gazing and see what the future of this rapidly evolving technology might hold.

Talk by Colin Eberhardt at the JS Monthly London Meetup.

Recorded by Pusher.com.

Pusher's channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCoyqucxoFXDFnh3khD0rjUg

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

topLevelComment.author: Rohit Kumar
topLevelComment.text:
For all the idiots talking about JS not dying... 

Dude, there are two javascript: 1. one that we write (now mostly people write typescript or other variant specific to framework) 2. Pure vanilla javascript target 
We stopped writing pure javascript long back and javascript remained only as a compilation target as described. 
The title actually mean The death of JavaScript as a compilation target

Now you might write in typescript or Rust or C, all will be compiled to WASM (I mean in near future)
Who knows, with WASI, WASM will become new platform independent target for other programming language.

topLevelComment.author: Bjarni Einarsson
topLevelComment.text:
Hmmm... measuring is not the same as measuring. Javascript is optimized. Cached.  So when you build a repeat loop of some code, the js compiler skip strait to execution.. no parsing etc. 
That is not the same as happen in the real world. Repeated code is a rare instance. 
Javascript need upgrade. Most vital thing is forward type declaration and strong type checking. Then things are much better for js compiler to parse and optimize.

topLevelComment.author: Paul Stoleriu
topLevelComment.text: Programmers that understand nothing about a language keep trying to replace it since the 90s, even though they already have other options. 2016/2017 and they finally develop a compilation target that's no faster than the old language, and has none of the features or bindings for the web APIs. These same programmers enforce static analysis into js frameworks for a dynamic language by adding a compile step negating all of the benefits of a dynamic language.

replies.author: Paul Stoleriu
Muhammad Seyan
replies.text: @Paul Stoleriu then back to the main discussion, why exactly do you think web assembly is nonsensical ? Since all compiled languages tend to be faster and provide better tooling than JS? JS is seriously not  performant enough. that's why online video editors and stuff use wasm

replies.author: Paul Stoleriu
replies.text: @Muhammad Seyan yeah fine, c++ with templates is not a static language, templates are compiled at run time. ansi c also had a dynamic back door with function pointers. turns out a static only language isn't that useful in practice, which only proves my general point.

replies.author: Muhammad Seyan
replies.text: @Paul Stoleriu "Compiled only languages have no dynamic data structures". ah yes, since you have never used any. Dynamic types are possible in most modern compiled only language. but it takes more effort. for example, C++'s templates provides ways to dynamically memory for any data. Come back when you have actually used a strongly typed language in prod

replies.author: Paul Stoleriu
replies.text:
@Muhammad Seyan 
1. there's no such thing as unstructured data. 
2. modern 'static' languages do have dynamic types like linked lists (pioneered by IPL and LISP) and trees but with limitations and work-arounds, and, of course, holes in the static type checker. which is why they need, and have a dynamic runtime (either a vm, jit compiler or some sort of evaluator for the run time data, or dynamic structures are provided by the OS). 
3. compiled only languages (like C for microcontrollers) don't have any dynamic data structures. 
4. your static type checker will never ever, and can't, type check dynamic data structures because runtime data is not evaluated at compile or link time, it is evaluated on run time and can only be type cheked on run time.
5. point number four is why you need to write tests and run them, or write code while running with some sort of REPL to debug. when working with dynamic data structures you can't debug without running the code, and a static type check will mostly do nothing at all.
6. because of number 5, adding another type checker to JS which already has both static and dynamic type evaluation is moronic considering all of the DOM is a dynamic data structure.

Compilers and code are as broken as their coders.

Each of those tools(cpp, java, javascript etc) is the sharpest knife in it's kitchen and could only be replaced with new one :) Why would u even have to learn all of them? Stick to a stack(1 to 4 tools) that helps u solve problems the best possible way and that's it. I believe it works so,  at least for me.

topLevelComment.author: Ajit Singh
topLevelComment.text: Nice clickbait, "Death of JavaScript"!!! Webassembly's potential seems to be compute intensive jobs in Browser, like games, in-browser databases, browser related programming itself, since Webassembly is running C/C++ code in browser natively. However, success of any programming language depends on its overall ecosystem of developers, tooling, plugins/packages, which JS has decades of maturity. For web applications / website development, JS is going to stay, may be a tiny portion of compute intensive work, might get ported to Webassembly.

topLevelComment.author: James Hardaker
topLevelComment.text: there are political powers at play that will not allow Web assembly to become useful. Apple don't want it because it would allow native like apps to run through its browser. Google don't want it because the more engaged the user is with web content the less adds you will notice.  This is why adds are ineffective in fast paced video games. Webassembly would bring desktop experiences into chrome, this is a disaster for advertising. Webassembly will make developers more productive reducing the number of licenses that companies need to pay. Compare Unity/Unreal Engine to the web developers tool set. Web dev tech is 15 years behind. We still build html tables with a text editor but build immersive 3d interactive worlds with an intuitive gui. Flash and SL were making some tracks in this direction but they were squashed by aforementioned companies for a variety of excuses.

The companies joining for Wasm are way to inhomogenous in their Business that they will all decide to keep Wasm in a "preliminary" state.
And at the end Wasm is basically open source, like JavaScript, developed - to some extent - by a non corporate community.
Wasm even has a 3D api, called Webgl, albeit a "interface layer" in JS is needed to access it from Wasm, what is likely to be improved for standardization and convenience.

replies.author: James Hardaker
replies.text:
it is currently is a state that is no threat to their platforms. It is only useful for very niche things atm - number crunching mainly.
They need to provide a 2d api including native text rendering so that 3rd party tool companies can build their own UI frameworks. I really want to see this work but im skeptical.

replies.author: Jakub Janek
replies.text: OOP is not the only way. Even Javascript was not intended to be oop. Only ES6 introduced classes and methods. Functional programming is getting really into mainstream again. WebAssembly is good for use of low level api's. WebGL or anything. You can get your authentification into WebAssembly to be a little more hidden or anything. It's something new that can be quite good at the end. And Rust language is supported so I think oop is a thing (using Structs and Implementations).

replies.author: Someone
replies.text:
It is designed to be a compilation target. I.e.: It's not supposed to be friendly for humans, but instead friendly for compilers. Compilers and compiler implementers don't care if their target is Object-Oriented or has X features. They care about predictability and simplicity.

Basically, it is not really competing with JavaScript per se: It's more like it is trying to enable other languages to compete with JavaScript, which is a Good Thing(tm).
